PM

Following the sharp move in the polls to Leave, we raise the probability of a vote to Leave to 45%. The result is on a knife-edge, although we expect a late swing in the polls to support an ultimate Remain victory.

PM

Strong move to Leave in recent polls: There has been a strong move to Leave of around 5pp in both internet polls and telephone polls over the last week, with the average of internet polls now showing a 4.7pp lead for Leave and the average of telephone polls now showing a much reduced 4.5pp lead for Remain. Our referendum tracker, which converts a polling difference into a probability and then averages across internet polls, telephone polls and the Betfair betting market (see UK Economics | EU Referendum: Remain Still Ahead, Leave Gains Ground (15 Apr 2016) for more detail on how we put it together) is now pointing to a 47% probability of a vote to Leave, up from 30% a week ago.

PM

Shifting to a 55% Remain / 45% Leave call: In response to this sharp move, we adjust our assessment of the probability of a vote to Leave. In line with the betting market, we continue to expect a vote to Remain, partly since our tracker still (just) gives the advantage to Remain, and partly as a result of the well-established phenomenon of a late swing to the status quo in referenda. However, we now raise the probability of a vote to Leave from 30% to 45%. This is the highest probability we have assigned to a Leave vote since we first published on the EU referendum in November 2015 and put the probability of a vote to Leave at 35% (see UK Economics & Strategy | EU Referendum: Insight: A Close Call (13 Nov 2015).

11:08 am
BE

(@TheLeggie: unbeaten so far.)

PM

Risks to the late swing: However, we see a significant risk to a late swing, given (i) the sharp poll move in recent days to Leave, and (ii) the possibility that the late swing to the status quo may be diluted if some voters see Leave as the lower risk option, if they are concerned about high immigration and associate EU membership with higher immigration .

11:20 am
BE

BWNG's 1Q trading deserves a strong share price reaction, in our view. This was
a challenging trading period, but we think product revenues rebounded into
positive growth over the last 6 weeks. At 8.4x PE & 6.6% div yield, the shares
appear braced for material disappointment and so have good reason to bounce.
The lasting takeaway here, we think, is that through the transformation
programme, BWNG is gaining flexibility to trade through tough markets.
Trading "in line" with expectations and unchanged FY guidance are the overriding
messages in today's update that we expect the market to respond positively to.
1Q Product Sales were -1.6% yoy vs -3% consensus (company compiled) - we had
looked for -4%. Product sales over the first 7 weeks of 1Q (13 weeks) were previously
reported as down yoy, and so look to us to have been in positive growth across the following
6 weeks. Lower marketing activity yoy early on in 1Q, as the group moved to smooth it across
1H this year, had exacerbated the early weakness, but this re-phasing should have benefited
the rest of 1Q. But we also suspect flexibility to trade the market conditions that unfolded to
have helped - the group notes "successful targeted promotions" drove sales (reduced ASPs
by low single digits but this was more than offset by higher average units per basket).
Online sales grew 6% yoy for the full 13 weeks (up 5ppts to 67% of the mix). Menswear
was up "mid-single digit" (product driven), Home and Gift broadly flat (tough comp),
Ladieswear "low single digit" decline (tough market), footwear "mid-single digit" decline.
The focus brands continue to respond. Most impressively, for the full period, product
rev growth at the JD Williams (JDW) brand was double digit and also up yoy for Simply Be
and Jacamo. All three achieved "healthy" active customer growth. As the principal focus
of group initiatives, these brands continue to respond to the strategy. Fifty Plus and
Traditional continue to drag. Weakness must have been significant at Fifty Plus as it
offset JDW brand growth, and combined (as they are officially reported at results), their
revs and active customer file declined "slightly". Fifty Plus will be migrated into JDW from
autumn, though we expect care and time to be taken to complete on that. Product revs
in Traditional (22% of FY16A mix) declined "mid-single" digits (was -5.5% FY16). Offer &
customer proposition improvements are timed to benefit Traditional from 2H.

BE

1Q Financial Services revenues up 3.4% yoy vs +2% consensus - fed by past debtor
book growth. JEFe had also looked for +2% growth.
Fit 4 the Future is on track "in all respects", including budget. New merchandising
systems have rolled out to plan. USA website launch (August) is the next milestone to note.
FCA authorisation process is developing in line with group expectations. USA continues to
find its own momentum with 17% constant currency growth over 1Q (FY16A was +20%).
While from a low base (£14m FY16 revs), the region does remain in "cautious expansion"
ahead of new website going live and after which we expect increased marketing support to
actively drive growth. The JD Williams brand launched in the USA In March. Ahead of the
Oct 11 interims (BWNG's next update), the group steers to expect a similar 1H/2H split to
FY16A (was 40%/60% at PBT).
Trough multiple on trough eps, strong balance sheet and DPS yield - BWNG trades
on 8.4x 12-month forward JEFe eps - at the bottom of its 8-19x 15-year range. We view EPS
as trending along trough levels ahead of the benefits Fit 4 the Future can bring. We see the
DPS flat this year and 1.7x covered by EPS and yielding 6.6%. The balance sheet is strong
(£290m net debt overshadowed by the £527m debtor book). From low levels, we think
today's confident trading update justifies an equally confident share price response. Buy.

BE

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Sales growth was -0.2% v cons -2% and UBSe -1%. Product sales were –1.6% v
cons -3% and UBSe -4% and Financial Services income +3.4% v cons +2% and UBSe
+6%. Power Brands were flat held back by the Fifty Plus title but core JD Wiliams saw
double digit growth which is reassuring. Traditional brands down mid-single digit.
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Product sales were better than expected and May likely saw a pick up. The credit
book provides some debate as we look into next week with no FX or overseas exposure
but any potential drop off in economic activity putting pressure on bad debts.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: No change to guidance although gross margin may be at the lower end given
increased promotions and sales growth a bit better than we thought.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: This is a rare sales beat with no change to PBT and given the very weak share price
we expect the shares to be up 2-4% but political concerns will likely remain top of
mind.

11:30 am
BE

- Poundland already issued a pre-close FYQ4 statement, reporting that LFL
sales for the full year decreased by 3.9% and guiding that Pre-tax Profits were
to be in line with market expectations (of £35.8m-£41.5m excluding the
trading losses from 99p stores). It is no surprise, therefore, that the actual
figure has come in at £37.8m.
- The company has additionally provided an update on current trading with
total group sales increasing by 30% for the 11 weeks to 12 June. These figures
are somewhat difficult to read given the acquisition and conversion of 99p
stores but the company is making clear that it expects "H1 to be challenging
with negative LFL growth".

BE

- Other guidance for FY16/17 includes 20-30 new store openings in the UK &
ROI (this lower level was already highlighted with the pre-close statement) and
a small number of stores in Spain. The net effect of the 99p stores conversion
programme is guided to add c.£350m to Group turnover with two-thirds of
the £25m annual EBITDA expected to be delivered this year.
- The company is proposing a final dividend of 2.00p, resulting in a total
dividend for the year of 3.65p, down nearly 20% YoY. Given that year end Net
Debt remains fairly low (£12m) we see this as a particularly powerful sign. We
have not spoken to the company this morning but we continue to see some
downside risk to forecasts, although the consensus range remains wide
(underlying Pre-tax Profits of £44m-£59m for FY16/17).
- Based on last night's closing price and existing consensus forecasts,
Poundland is trading on 16.2x calendar 2016 earnings, 8.4x EBITDA, with a
2.5% dividend yield. This compares with the UK General Retail sector on 14.0x,
8.2x and 3.3% respectively.

BE

And Canaccord.

11:31 am
BE

On a short-term basis, the shares will clearly be driven more by the news of a potential
offer from Steinhoff than on underlying trading fundamentals. With regard to the latter,
the LFL performance in Q1 has remained stubbornly in negative territory. While an
element of this can, in our view, still be attributed to disruption from the accelerated
conversion of 99p to Poundland, there remains an issue on underlying trading weakness,
reflecting a combination of adverse weather impact and declining High Street footfall.
Comparatives ease in H2, but the market will have to wait until evidence emerges on
whether Poundland's self-help measures can return LFL sales into positive territory.

BE

The shares were trading between 150p and 155p ahead of Warburg Pincus selling
its remaining 15% stake at a 25% premium on Tuesday. Following yesterday's
announcement from Steinhoff that it is considering a possible offer for Poundland, the
shares are trading on a cal 16E PER of 15.6x (adding back 99p's FY16 trading losses)
falling to 12.2x for cal 17E. The corresponding EV/EBITDA are 8.4x and 6.0x.

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 135.96, down 0.5443 (-0.40%), High: 137.90, Low: 134.15, Volume: 18.67m
BE

We upgrade GLEN to BUY setting a price objective of GBp190 based on 1x our DCF/multiple derived SOTP.
3 key reasons. 1) Balance sheet repair largely "in hand". 2) Glen's commodities, esp. coal and copper, going right way.
3) China macro OK if not compelling. 2016E FCF US$3 bn implies about 11% FCF yield.

11:38 am
BE

It continues ..........

BE

Upgrade to BUY. Balance sheet. Commodities. China macro.

We upgrade Glencore to BUY setting a price objective of GBp190 based on 1x our DCF/multiple derived SOTP. Three key reasons for our change of view. 1) Balance sheet repair largely "in hand" with a clear path to more deleveraging if/as required. 2) GLEN's commodities, particularly copper & coal, are going the right way. 3) China Macro is OK if not compelling. Glencore should generate around US$3 bn this year, ex working capital moves (which should, we think, be net beneficial), implying about 11% FCF yield.

BE

Balance sheet repair "in hand". $7.3 bn raised. More coming?

Glencore was one of the first "Big Miners" to acknowledge its balance sheet issues with its equity raise and deleveraging plan announced in September 2015. Since then the company has acted decisively raising c. $7.3 bn broken down as $2.5 bn in new equity and around US$4.8 bn in asset sales. To the surprise of many (including us) the asset market seems quite "liquid" and, as a general trend, asset pricing is surprising to the upside. From here, pending disposals include 1) Coal infrastructure 2) Kazakh gold mines and, possibly, two smaller copper mines (Lomas Bayas and Cobar).

11:39 am
BE

Coal and copper are going the right way

After our tactically bearish call on copper earlier this year, we now see upside in copper to greater than US$5000/t driven by a Chinese stocking cycle. Thermal coal has been structurally oversupplied with the Chinese stepping back from the seaborne market but we now see less overhang from local supply as the Chinese government pushes supply side discipline with its new 276 work days rule. Local Chinese seaborne coal prices increased 10 yuan/t in June. While zinc and nickel are relatively less important products for GLEN, zinc fundamentals look compelling in our view and nickel could be bottoming.

BE

China: Signs of stabilization after a period of volatility

At the end of 2015, the market was concerned on potential for a hard landing. In Q1 we had commodity market gyrations driven by restocking & speculative flows. Our economists now highlight growth stabilization in May despite softer manufacturing investment.

BE

On the other side of things, UBS pushing gold.

11:41 am
BE

Strategy, this. Take from it whatever you wish.

BE

We have been bullish gold for some time
We became constructive on gold last October on the back of: 1) the expectation that
lower US equilibrium real rates versus previous cycles (and versus what markets were
initially anticipating) should be supportive for gold, 2) low positioning given the market
had been correcting the past couple of years in anticipation of Fed normalisation and
better global growth, and 3) relatively stable supply and demand fundamentals which
would limit further downside.

BE

Fundamentals and technicals suggest more upside to come
We think gold still has room to go higher from here. We continue to expect support to
come from 1) real rates remaining low (or negative in some cases), 2) the dollar having
peaked vs DM currencies, 3) room for further investor inflows, and 4) lingering macro
risks. We expect gold to strengthen towards the latter part of Q3 through to Q4,
potentially testing $1350 later this year particularly as seasonal physical demand kicks
in. The anticipation of a possible Fed rate hike in September (UBS base case) is likely to
weigh on gold, but we expect this impact to be temporary. The market should swiftly
recover on the back of safe haven demand, as Fed tightening will ultimately lead back
to more macro uncertainty and risk aversion.

11:41 am
BE

But there is a risk we have come too far, too fast
Gold has rallied as much as $250 from the lows printed in Q4 last year. Given our base
case that prices would average $1225 this year, the upside prospects from current
levels are less generous than they were last December, when we first published our
forecast in Resetting expectations. Physical demand for gold has also been weaker than
anticipated. Nevertheless, the move in gold YTD, the increase/breadth of interest, and
the shift/resilience of sentiment have been more forceful than we initially anticipated.
While this creates scope for more upside relative to our base case, we continue to think
that strategic reallocation to gold will take time to play out.

BE

BE

11:51 am
BE

We analyse the lower guidance that led to profit downgrades and examine the self-exclusion issue in detail. Our findings, as well as an early bond refinancing, lead us to downgrade FY16E/FY17E operating profit by 15.3%/18.1% with downside risk to forecasts. While we acknowledge the share buyback may provide some short-term support, internal issues not seen by competitors, technology risk, and regulatory headwinds combine to create a bleak outlook. We downgrade to REDUCE with a target price of 286p.

BE

FY17E at risk from self-exclusion: We believe William Hill has given itself enough headroom to meet FY16 forecasts post lowering operating profit guidance, but forecasts are at risk for FY17. If levels of automatic self-exclusions do not subside, we estimate this could cost William Hill between £24.1m and £36.3m at the EBIT level (and more if numbers worsen).
Internal issues: Issues were seen with migrating players to Project Trafalgar in Q315, some of which seem to be ongoing. William Hill is yet to transition desktop customers, with c.55%-60% of sportsbook revenue generated via desktop including redirected mobile web customers. We argue that this is a FY16E risk that should not be ignored.
The gambling industry has been hit by punitive regulation, but the full effect is still to be seen. The regulatory landscape is undeniably challenging with free bet taxation, the racing levy, online automatic self-exclusion, cross operator self-exclusion in retail and online, possible further FOBT regulation from the Triennial Review (no date has been set), reality checks and implementation thereof, and further AML procedures (4th AMLD).
Management changes: The majority of executive team members (7 of 12) have been replaced recently, since James Henderson arrived at the helm. Arguably, too much change in management brings upheaval and may distract from the day-to-day running of the business.
Valuation: Our new SoTP-based target price of 286p (previously 404p) implies 8.9x FY17E EBITDA. We downgrade our recommendation from Add to Reduce.

PM

The DB Real Estate team believes that material changes in buy-to-let (BTL)
economics create a potential shock to London's illiquid residential property
market. New tax rules will reduce BTL returns on equity towards zero and
result in low or negative cashflow, particularly for new landlords. Meanwhile,
new mortgage regulation could severely restrict the ability of investors to use
leverage to buy properties. We expect these changes to result in a substantial
fall in BTL purchases (c.40% of purchases in recent years) and some selling.
This has the potential to be a major drag on a market where

PM

Material change in buy-to-let economics to drive substantial demand decline
Buy-to-let (BTL) faces a number of challenges in the coming years. 2017-21
sees a major deterioration in buy-to-let economics for many owners driven by
changes to interest tax deductibility and 2nd home stamp duty. This is
especially negative for a new purchaser at current yields. For a property with a
3.5% gross rental yield, a purchaser on an interest only-mortgage faces a net
cash yield of 0-0.5% and ROE of 0-1% pre maintenance and capital / rental
growth. We expect new buying to fall materially accelerated by regulation.
Future regulation to have a substantial impact on London demand
New proposed regulation (expected H2 16) will also hurt BTL demand we
believe. Interacting with low yields (~3.5%) and tax changes, new stress tests
for banks may create a situation where only very low loan-to-value (

PM

Some selling also likely, especially if rates rise or pricing declines.
Some selling by existing landlords is also likely driven by lower returns
(especially if rates rise or pricing declines). Our detailed historic analysis of
cohorts of landlords over the past 15 years suggests that a material number of
owners will face pain and squeezes on returns. While the tax deductibility
regulation only applies to higher rate taxpayers, having to put ‘gross rent’ as
opposed to ‘net income’ in tax returns means a substantial number of lower
rate taxpayers will become higher rate taxpayers.
London market to move into imbalance – major shock event possible
The number of sellers compared to buyers (not S/D of dwelling stock) sets
pricing and the market has been illiquid since the financial crisis (only 3.5% of
stock turns over pa). BTL potentially swings from a low turn segment to a
material source of supply. We think this has the potential to create a major
shock to the market due to a significant decline in London BTL demand, some
selling (especially for flats/ the FTB market) and incrementally more housing
supply (too much supply in prime). We think stretched affordability will offset
population growth. Help-to-Buy is a substantial support behind the new build
market but new build is only c.20% of annual transactions.

Additions? Here they come.

BE

The high fragmentation of the customer care interaction market creates a number of
opportunities for consolidation in this space. On January 18, 2016, we initiated on
Teleperformance, applying a rank of 2 based on our Business services M&A framework.
Our Telecom analysts have moved Bouygues to a rank of 2 (from a rank of 4) given the
managements of Orange and Bouygues Telecom have formally announced talks, indicating
that Bouygues appears to be a willing seller.
Elsewhere in the Telecoms, our analysts have included a 20% M&A premium weight in the
price target of Tele Columbus to reflect the stock’s strategic appeal. As the final large-
scale, independent cable operator left in Germany with no blocking stakeholder, our
analysts believe that Tele Columbus presents an attractive M&A target and believe that
meaningful synergies could accrue to any larger scale cable operator.
In the Media space, as the worlds of media and telecoms converge, with BT, Sky and
TalkTalk all entering the mobile market, and Vodafone potentially entering TV, our analyst
sees Sky as a strategic target, given the stickiness of the TV product and its growing
pipeline of in-house content. A hypothetical move towards pan-European selling of rights
could also incentivize further pan-European consolidation.
Our Oil team applies an M&A premium to strategic oil rich assets. Our analysts view the
‘SNE’ project as one of the few non-Brazilian deepwater projects that can thrive in the new
world of US$60 pricing. Accordingly, they attach an M&A premium (rank of 1; 50% M&A
weighting) to the asset in their SOTP valuation of Cairn Energy.
In the Financial space, our Real estate team incorporates an M&A score of 2 (from 3) in
case of PSP Swiss Property based on the fact that stocks trading at a discount to NNNAV
are potentially interesting to corporate acquirers and that those with particularly high levels
of cost can offer potential synergies to an acquirer.
In the Biotech space, Zealand Pharma screens as an attractive target (Rank of 1).
Zealand’s key asset (lixisenatide), is partnered with Sanofi. It has recently passed an FDA
advisory committee vote, and hence is largely a derisked asset. In achieving FDA approval
(PDUFA set for August 2016) and also with a sales launch, Zealand triggers a set of royalty
payments, and hence an associated increase in cash flow. As a result, our analyst believes
that Zealand offers significant strategic appeal.
